newsitem.title: afghanistan: Taleban say repulse Afghan opposition offensive.
newsitem.headline: Taleban say repulse Afghan opposition offensive.

text.p: The Taleban have repulsed an offensive launched by opposition forces north of Kabul but lost some territory, a Taleban commander said on Wednesday.
"(Opposition forces) had secretly deployed a number of their groups and ambushed a some of our vehicles, but we repulsed the attack.
"They had a plan to take the high ground and cut the road," said Mullah Khair Mohammed, commander of the Taleban forces on at the frontline at Jabal-os-Siraj, some 80 km (50 miles) north of Kabul.
"Our defensive line here is unchanged, but we lost some artillery spotting positions and ambush points." he added.
The Afghan opposition alliance, based in the north of the country, said on Wednesday it had launched a major offensive and advanced about 10 km (six miles).
The alliance, consisting of forces of the government that the Taleban ousted from Kabul last September and northern leader General Abdul Rashid Dostum, launched the attack on Tuesday morning.
The Afghan Islamic Press, a private Pakistan-based news agency, quoted witnesses as saying several Taleban were killed in the attack.
Khair Mohammed said that no Taleban fighters had been killed, and denied reports that 70 of his men had been captured, saying only three had been taken.
"The opposition have captured a number of travellers on the road and are calling them Taleban." he said.
"We captured five opposition fighters and there were some dead bodies, which we pushed into the river."
It was not immediately possible to confirm his statement.
Journalists visiting Jabal-os-Siraj on Wednesday saw one captured opposition fighter in the back of a Taleban truck with his hands tied behind his back.
Khair Mohammed said that he was waiting for an order from his superiors to launch an attack against the opposition.

Taleban and opposition troops were exchanging salvoes of fire from Soviet-built multiple rocket launchers on Wednesday morning. The Taleban were targetting a ridge overlooking Jabal- os-Siraj, with the opposition hitting the town itself.
Few civilians appeared in the town on Wednesday. The Taleban have moved most of the civilian population from the areas north of Kabul, fearful of an uprising against their troops.
Tuesday's attack was the first major offensive on Jabal-os-Siraj since the Taleban took it from the alliance on January 23.
